Award.AwardTitle: IRES-International Research Experience in Nanotechnology-NNIN and NIMS 2010
Award.AbstractNarration:
To be effective professionally the coming generation of scientists must learn to contribute within the global research environment and be globally aware scientists. An understanding of how research is conducted in different cultures, how local culture affects science and engineering, and how one should communicate effectively internationally, is part of the necessary learning. A standard curriculum or US-based research experience can't teach this.

This program will support 5 advanced undergraduate researchers each summer for three years for an intense and advanced research experience at a National Laboratory in Japan. Participants will be drawn from prior years' NNIN REU program. This assures that the students have a well formed baseline of research experience from which to build and that we have a reliable assessment of their potential. The foreign partners at the National Institute for Materials Science in Japan have proven to be most effective and willing hosts for our students.

This experience will come at a critical time in the participants' careers as they prepare for graduate school. Through this program they will advance their research skills, expand their knowledge in nanotechnology, expand their cultural horizons, and gain confidence that they can contribute effectively in a challenging international context, and be effective global scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific research is now a global enterprise, and to be successful, young scientists must be able to not only function but thrive within the global research environment. While science itself is universal, the way that scientists communicate and interact with each other is not; there is a strong cultural component. To be successful young scientists must learn to collaborate with colleagues in other countries and to take advantage of their expertise or facilities. This concept is well recognized within multinational corporations where considerable effort is devoted to training and evaluation of “cultural intelligence”. Foreign students in science and engineering recognize early that they must have international experience, particularly in the US, to be successful. US undergraduate students, graduate students, or even post-docs do not, however, often have the same exposure, either by desire or opportunity. This puts them at a significant disadvantage compared to their international peers. The purpose of this program is to give a highly select group of students an early career nanotechnology research experience in an international environment and to thereby significantly enhance their future scientific careers.

This program supported an international research experience for 15 students total over the life of the award.   Three cadres of students were participated, in the summers of 2011, 2012, 2013. Our primary collaborator for this program was the National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS) in Tsukaba, Japan, a world-class nanotechnology facility. (Due to the Great Tsunami of 2011, for safety reasons after consultation with NSF ,the 2011 cadre was sent to several facilities in Europe; this did not change or affect the overall mission or result the program, however).The 15 students supported here were part of a larger cadre of students supported by other funds of the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network. Projects covered the range for nanotechnology including projects related to biomedicine, chemical synthesis, materials growth and characterization, electronic devices, and energy.

Selection for participation in the program was highly selective. Participants were drawn exclusively as a subset from alumni of the Research Experience for Undergraduates program of the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network, itself a highly selective program. While in Japan or Europe, the students each completed an independent research project in collaboration with a senior scientist , networked with scientists from the host country as well as countries from around the world, visited laboratories around the host country, and while in Japan met with NSF officials in Tokyo.  They communicated their results in a end of program conference at the host laboratory; many of these projects have resulted or will result in peer reviewed publications.  Lastly, they returned to the US and presented their results and their foreign experience to almost 100 younger students in the NNIN REU Program.

The human resource impacts of this program play out over the long term and these students progress in their careers. Many of the participants in this three year program have not even graduated from college yet. Historically, however, extrapolating from previously funded similar programs, most of these students go on to excel in leading graduate school in science and engineering. Furthermore, almost 50% of them end up receiving NSF Graduate Fellowships based at least in part on their participation in this program.

This program demonstrated that select undergraduate students can succeed and in fact thrive in an advanced international research laboratory, adapting well to the new culture and environment.
